papers.title: Probing habitable regions with SRG/eROSITA
papers.abstract: Stellar high-energy radiation is a key driver of atmospheric erosion and evolution in exoplanets, directly affecting their long-term habitability. We present a comprehensive study on stellar high-energy radiation and its impact on exoplanetary atmospheres, leveraging data from the SRG/eROSITA all-sky survey. Our sample consists of 3750 main-sequence stars identified by cross-matching with Gaia DR3. Utilizing X-ray spectral fits from the eROSITA catalog, we computed X-ray (L_X) and combined extreme-ultraviolet (EUV) luminosities (L‚ÇêthrmEUV), which we used to derive XUV fluxes at the habitable zone (F‚ÇêthrmXUV,HZ). We find that the majority of stars in our sample are significantly more XUV-active than the Sun, with habitable zone fluxes ranging from 10‚Å∞ to 10‚Åµ erg cm‚Åª¬≤ s‚Åª¬π. The ratio of L‚ÇêthrmXUV/L‚Çêthrmb‚Çíl is found to be higher for cooler, magnetically active stars, highlighting their potentially hazardous nature for planetary atmospheres. Applying the energy-limited escape model, we computed atmospheric mass-loss rates for hypothetical earth-like planets located at the habitable zone of each star. We also present local maps for distances up to 500 pc of the average XUV flux, revealing ``hazard zones'' where stellar radiation could significantly influence planetary atmospheric evolution. This work demonstrates the power of X-ray surveys in constraining the high-energy environments of exoplanets and underscores the critical role of stellar activity in planetary habitability.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

When we search for life beyond Earth, we're not just looking for planets in the right place‚Äîwe need to know if they can actually keep their atmospheres. Think of a planet's atmosphere like a protective blanket that makes life possible. But stars aren't always gentle neighbors. They blast nearby planets with intense radiation that can strip away these atmospheric blankets over millions of years, leaving behind barren, Mars-like worlds. Understanding which stars are "atmosphere killers" versus "life nurturers" is crucial for knowing where to focus our search for alien life and whether Earth-like worlds can truly stay Earth-like over cosmic time.

**What They Did**

Scientists used a powerful space-based X-ray telescope called eROSITA to study the radiation environments around 3,750 nearby stars. They measured how much high-energy radiation‚ÄîX-rays and extreme ultraviolet light‚Äîeach star produces. Then, like cosmic real estate agents, they calculated how much of this dangerous radiation would hit a planet located in each star's "habitable zone"‚Äîthe just-right distance where liquid water could exist on a planet's surface. Finally, they used computer models to estimate how quickly this radiation would strip away the atmosphere of an Earth-like planet orbiting each star.

**Key Findings**

The results were sobering: most stars in our cosmic neighborhood are far more violent than our Sun. While our Sun provides a relatively gentle radiation environment, many nearby stars bombard their habitable zones with radiation levels ranging from equal to our Sun's output up to 100,000 times more intense. The research revealed that smaller, cooler stars‚Äîwhich make up the majority of stars in our galaxy‚Äîare often the worst offenders, creating "hazard zones" where Earth-like atmospheres would be stripped away relatively quickly.

**Looking Forward**

This research provides astronomers with a cosmic roadmap for prioritizing exoplanet targets. Rather than assuming all stars are equally hospitable, we now know which stellar neighborhoods offer the best chances for long-term habitability, helping focus future telescope observations on the most promising worlds.

papers.title: The effect of JWST/NIRSpec data reduction on the retrieval of WASP-39b atmospheric properties
papers.abstract: The JWST provides exoplanet transit observations with unprecedented spectral coverage, enabling detailed atmospheric characterisation. However, systematics introduced during data reduction can lead to small but significant uncertainties that propagate into atmospheric retrievals, making it essential to assess their impact on inferred properties. We aim to quantify the impact of different JWST/NIRSpec PRISM data-reduction processes as well as the relevance of saturation on the retrieved atmospheric properties of WASP-39b. We also assess whether or not these biases are comparable to those introduced by assumptions made in atmospheric modelling, particularly in the treatment of aerosol extinction. We perform nested-sampling Bayesian retrievals using MultiNest and forward models generated with the Planetary Spectrum Generator. Six independently reduced spectra are analysed, considering both the full wavelength range and versions excluding the saturated region. We further test the effect of including three different cloud-opacity parameterisations. Differences among JWST/NIRSpec data-reduction pipelines lead to substantial variations in retrieved atmospheric properties of WASP-39b, often exceeding one order of magnitude, comparable to uncertainties from modelling assumptions. Excluding the saturated region reduces inter-pipeline dispersion but increases parameter degeneracies. This highlights the need for robust and homogeneous calibration strategies. The results also confirm that JWST data possess the sensitivity required to probe aerosol spectral behaviour, although such constraints remain strongly dependent on the adopted data-reduction strategy.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to diagnose a patient's health, but getting wildly different results depending on which lab processes your blood sample. That's essentially what's happening with our most powerful space telescope as it studies distant worlds. The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) can peer into the atmospheres of planets orbiting other stars‚Äîcalled exoplanets‚Äîwith incredible detail, potentially revealing which worlds might harbor life. But this groundbreaking research has uncovered a troubling problem: the way scientists process the telescope's raw data dramatically affects what we think we know about these alien worlds. Getting this right isn't just about scientific accuracy‚Äîit could determine whether we correctly identify potentially habitable planets or miss them entirely.

**What They Did**

The researchers focused on WASP-39b, a well-studied planet about 700 light-years away that's roughly the size of Saturn but orbits much closer to its star. When this planet passes in front of its star, the telescope can analyze starlight filtering through the planet's atmosphere, like studying a sunset through Earth's air. Six different research teams processed the same telescope observations using their own methods, like six photographers developing the same film negative with different techniques. The scientists then used computer models to interpret what gases and clouds might exist in the planet's atmosphere based on each processed dataset. They also tested what happened when they excluded data from parts of the detector that were overwhelmed by bright light.

**Key Findings**

The results were shocking: depending on which team processed the data, the estimated amounts of atmospheric components varied by more than ten times. This is like six labs analyzing the same blood sample and one finding normal cholesterol while another finds dangerously high levels. Even more concerning, these processing differences created uncertainties just as large as those from the assumptions scientists make about how clouds and hazes behave in alien atmospheres. When the researchers excluded the problematic bright-light data, the results became more consistent between teams, but they lost some ability to distinguish between different atmospheric possibilities.

**Looking Forward**

This research sounds an important alarm for exoplanet science. As we search for signs of life on distant worlds, we need to ensure our tools are giving us accurate readings. The study shows that JWST has the sensitivity to detect the subtle signatures of clouds and hazes in alien atmospheres‚Äîa crucial capability for understanding these worlds. However, the astronomical community must develop standardized methods for processing telescope data, much like medical labs follow strict protocols to ensure reliable results. Without this consistency, we risk drawing incorrect conclusions about potentially life-bearing worlds, making this technical challenge one of the most important hurdles in our quest to find life beyond Earth.

papers.title: Dilution of accreted planetary matter in hot DA white dwarfs according to their mass
papers.abstract: A large proportion of observed white dwarfs (WDs) show evidence of debris disks, remnants of the former planetary systems, and/or signatures of heavy elements in their atmospheres, induced by the accretion of planetary matter onto their surfaces. The observed abundances are the result of the balance between the accretion flux and the dilution of this planetary material by internal transport processes. A recent study showed that more massive DA WDs are less polluted than smaller mass ones. It was suggested that the reason could be related to the formation of planetary systems when these stars were on the main sequence. The aim of this work is to test how internal dilution processes, including thermohaline convection, change with WD masses, and whether such an effect could account for variations in the observed pollution. We computed the efficiency of atomic diffusion and thermohaline convection after the accretion of heavy elements onto WDs using static DA models with various masses, effective temperatures, and hydrogen contents. We confirm that thermohaline convection is always more efficient in diluting accreted elements than atomic diffusion, as previously shown in the literature. However, we find that element dilution by thermohaline convection is less efficient in massive WDs than in smaller mass ones, due to their larger internal density. We showed that the differences in observed heavy element pollution in WDs according to their masses cannot be explained by the dilution induced by atomic diffusion and thermohaline mixing alone. Indeed, the pollution by planetary system accretion should be more easily detectable in massive WDs than in low-mass ones. We discuss other processes that should be taken into account before drawing any conclusion about the occurrences of planetary systems according to the mass of the star on the main sequence.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

When stars like our Sun die, they become white dwarfs‚Äîincredibly dense, Earth-sized remnants that slowly cool over billions of years. These stellar corpses offer us a unique window into the fate of planetary systems, including what might happen to our own solar system in about 5 billion years. Many white dwarfs show signs of "pollution"‚Äîheavy elements like calcium and iron in their atmospheres that shouldn't be there. These elements are like cosmic fingerprints, revealing that the white dwarf has been feeding on the remnants of destroyed planets, asteroids, and comets from its former planetary system. Understanding this process helps us learn how common planetary systems are and what ultimately happens to the rocky worlds orbiting dying stars.

**What They Did**

The researchers used computer models to simulate what happens when planetary debris falls onto white dwarfs of different masses. Think of it like dropping food coloring into different containers of water‚Äîsome might mix the color throughout quickly, while others might keep it concentrated near the surface. The scientists specifically looked at two mixing processes: atomic diffusion (like slow stirring) and thermohaline convection (like the vigorous mixing that happens when you pour cold cream into hot coffee). They tested these processes across white dwarfs with various masses, temperatures, and hydrogen content to see how efficiently each type would dilute the incoming planetary material throughout their interior.

**Key Findings**

The results revealed a cosmic paradox. Previous observations showed that more massive white dwarfs appear less polluted by planetary debris than their lighter counterparts. Scientists initially thought this might be because more massive stars had fewer planets to begin with. However, this study found the opposite should be true: massive white dwarfs are actually worse at mixing planetary material throughout their interiors due to their higher internal density. This means pollution should be more easily detectable in massive white dwarfs, not less. The mixing process that dominates‚Äîthermohaline convection‚Äîworks less efficiently in dense, massive white dwarfs, like trying to stir thick honey versus water.

**Looking Forward**

This discovery means we need to rethink our understanding of planetary system evolution around dying stars. Since internal mixing processes can't explain why massive white dwarfs appear less polluted, other factors must be at play. Perhaps more massive stars really did have fewer planets during their lifetimes, or maybe the planetary destruction process itself works differently around various types of white dwarfs. This research pushes scientists to develop more sophisticated models of how planetary systems meet their end, ultimately helping us better predict the long-term fate of worlds throughout the galaxy.

papers.title: Satellites and small bodies with ALMA: Insights into Solar System formation & evolution
papers.abstract: Our understanding of the formation and evolution of planetary systems has made major advances in the past decade. This progress has been driven in large part by the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA), which has given us an unprecedented view of Solar System bodies themselves, and of the structure and chemistry of forming exoplanetary systems. Within our own Solar System, ALMA has enabled the detection of new molecules and isotopologues across moons and comets, as well as placing new constraints on the compositions and histories of small bodies through thermal emission observations. In this article, we highlight some key areas where ALMA has contributed to a deeper understanding of our Solar System's formation and evolution, and place these discoveries in the context of our evolving understanding of protoplanetary disks.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to understand how your family formed by studying both old family photos and meeting distant relatives. That's essentially what astronomers are doing to understand how planetary systems‚Äîincluding our own Solar System‚Äîcome to be. By studying the moons, comets, and asteroids in our cosmic backyard alongside forming planetary systems around other stars, scientists are piecing together the epic story of how worlds are born. This research matters because it helps us understand our own origins and whether Earth-like planets might be common or rare in the universe. Every small body in our Solar System is like a time capsule, preserving clues about conditions billions of years ago when the planets were first forming from a swirling disk of gas and dust.

**What They Did**

Researchers used the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array‚Äîa collection of 66 radio telescopes in Chile's desert that work together like one giant eye in the sky. Think of it as a cosmic thermometer and chemical detector rolled into one. The team pointed these telescopes at various moons and comets in our Solar System, measuring the heat they give off and analyzing the unique fingerprints of different molecules in space. By detecting these faint signals, they could identify specific chemicals and even different versions of the same molecules (called isotopes) that reveal where and how these objects formed. They then compared these local discoveries with observations of young planetary systems around other stars to find common patterns.

**Key Findings**

The research revealed new molecules and chemical variants never before detected on Solar System moons and comets, essentially expanding our cosmic periodic table. These discoveries showed that small bodies preserve a much richer chemical record than previously thought, with some molecules acting like frozen-in-time signatures of the ancient Solar System's temperature and chemistry. The observations also revealed that the thermal properties of asteroids and comets provide new constraints on their internal structure and composition‚Äîimagine using a thermometer to figure out what's inside a wrapped present. Perhaps most excitingly, the chemical fingerprints found in our Solar System's small bodies match patterns seen in the dusty disks where new planets are currently forming around young stars.

**Looking Forward**

This research transforms how scientists search for and study exoplanets by providing a detailed reference guide of what planetary system formation looks like up close. Just as detectives use local crime scene evidence to solve cases elsewhere, astronomers can now use our Solar System's chemical clues to better interpret observations of distant planetary systems. This could help identify which young star systems are most likely to develop Earth-like worlds and guide future space missions to the most promising targets in our search for life beyond Earth.

papers.title: Real time, cross platform visualizations with zero dependencies for the N-body package REBOUND
papers.abstract: Visualizations have become an indispensable part of the scientific process. A vibrant ecosystem of visualization tools exists, catering to a wide variety of different needs. Real-time visualizations of numerical simulations offer scientists immediate feedback about the status of their simulations and can also be valuable educational and outreach tools. Developing a visualization tool with support for different operating systems, CPU/GPU architectures, and programming languages can be a challenge. It is common to use one or more graphics or UI libraries to act as abstraction layers and hide the underlying complexity. Whereas external libraries greatly simplify the initial programming effort, we argue that relying on them introduces new dependencies and problems, such as a higher entry barriers for new developers and users, and uncertainty regarding long-term support. In this paper we present a new approach for real time visualizations which we have implemented for the N-body package REBOUND. We propose to use a web browser to handle GPU accelerated rendering. This enables us to offer 3D, interactive visualizations on all major operating systems. What makes our new approach unique is that we achieve this without the need for any external libraries. We utilize WebAssembly to reuse existing OpenGL visualization code. Using communication via HTTP and a custom built-in web server, we are able to provide both local and remote real time visualizations. In addition to the browser based real time visualization, our approach offers other additional operating modes, including simulations running entirely within the browser, visualizations within jupyter notebooks, and traditional standalone visualizations using OpenGL. We focus on the implementation in REBOUND but the concepts and ideas discussed can be applied to many other areas in need of scientific and non-scientific real time visualizations.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

When astronomers discover new planets orbiting distant stars, they don't just want to crunch numbers‚Äîthey want to see these alien worlds in action. Imagine trying to understand how our solar system works by only reading spreadsheets instead of watching planets actually orbit the Sun. Scientists studying exoplanets face a similar challenge when running complex computer simulations that predict how these distant planetary systems behave over millions of years. This research tackles a surprisingly practical problem: how to create stunning, real-time visualizations of planetary motion that work on any computer, anywhere in the world, without the technical headaches that usually come with sophisticated graphics software.

**What They Did**

The researchers developed a clever new approach to visualizing planetary simulations using an unlikely tool: web browsers. Instead of relying on specialized graphics software that only works on certain computers or requires complex installation, they figured out how to make any standard web browser‚Äîthe same one you use to check email‚Äîdisplay interactive 3D animations of planets orbiting their stars. Think of it like turning your browser into a personal planetarium. They built this system for REBOUND, a popular software package that simulates how gravitational forces move planets around over time. The key innovation was creating a system with "zero dependencies"‚Äîmeaning it works immediately without users having to install additional software or worry about compatibility issues.

**Key Findings**

The team successfully created a visualization system that runs on all major operating systems and devices without requiring any external software libraries. Their approach offers multiple viewing options: scientists can watch simulations in real-time on their local computer, access them remotely through any web browser, or even run entire planetary simulations directly within the browser itself. The system also works seamlessly within Jupyter notebooks, a popular tool among researchers.

**Looking Forward**

This breakthrough could democratize access to sophisticated planetary science tools, allowing students, educators, and researchers worldwide to explore exoplanetary systems without technical barriers. As we discover thousands more exoplanets, having user-friendly visualization tools will help scientists better understand these alien worlds and communicate their findings to the public.
